I could take a high speed train from Nanjing to Shanghai in about 1.5 hours!In contrast, I took an Amtrak train from Detroit to Chicago (about 300 miles/480 km) and it took over 8 hours!Another area China wins at is public utilities. They provide electricity, water, and gas for billions of people for very affordable prices! I paid maybe a total of $20 (US) per month for all utility bills, whereas it cost me over $100 in America! There are more than twice as many high-speed trains in China as the rest of the world combined. The picture below is an early morning photo at the train station of a second-tier city in China.Tier 1 cities like Beijing have a couple hundred high-speed trains stopping at the city every day.And the Chinese Spring Festival is just a mad house - an estimated 3 billion person/trips take place within a 2-week window. It would be the equivalent of every American taking 10 trips during Christmas, or every European taking 5 trips during Christmas. All the train tickets are gone within like 10 seconds after they become available.The Chinese high-speed rail system made 1.5 billion trips last year, growing 30% a year. It’s just absolutely massive!

Because that is how human societies have responded to virtually every invader. If it turns out that the aliens won’t make the deal, then the elites will send us out to fight the aliens, while hiding in their bunkers for as long as possible; and again, they will tell us anything they think we need to hear to make that happen. It won’t be mankind against the aliens; it will be the elites of the world against the aliens, with the remainder of mankind as expendables.

Current scientific estThis is Earth OKThis is the solar system in which Earth resides. We are surrounded by several other planets and orbit a star we call the sun.Further out in space, there are several solar systems surrounding ours forming what we call the Solar Interstellar Neighborhood. Each of these solar systems contains stars and planets.See that tiny, tiny dot? So tiny you can’t even see it? That is our Solar Interstellar System. From here, we can’t even make out our solar system let alone individual planets. The galaxy is enormous. We are rotating what is believed to be a black hole. Current scientific estimates conclude that there are approximately 100 billion stars in our galaxy alone with planets orbiting them.As we travel further into space, the entire galaxy becomes just a dot of light. Each of those other dots are other galaxies.Further away, it is possible to see the Virgo Supercluster. That red notation represents our local galactic group, containing all of the galaxies near us. In that is the Milky Way galaxy. In that is the solar interstellar neighborhood. In that is our solar system. In that is planet Earth.The local supercluster group contains the virgo supercluster, where we are located, as well as the other superclusters near us.That tiny dot that you can hardly make out on the screen is the Virgo Supercluster. All of those other dots are superclusters. And this is just the observable universe that we can estimate. It is believed that there are countless, perhaps even infinite, other dimensions. Theoretically, planet Earth could have entire civilizations that exist in other dimensions we can’t access or interact with at the present time. Then there is the issue of time and gravity. If time travel is possible, all of these universes would be occurring at the same time everywhere in all dimensions.Multiverse?The multiverse is a hypothetical group of multiple universes.Together, these universes comprise everything that exists: the entirety of space, time, matter, energy, information, and the physical laws and constants that describe them.Do you still think we are alone in the Universe?

Answer: The reason it is so hard to predict what the state of human space colonization would be around 400 years in the future is that the rate of technological advancement is exponential, and often as a civilization we underestimate what we can achieve. There was a time when Lord Kelvin said "Heavier than air flying machines are impossible", and today air travel is part and parcel of our lives.Do I think we can advance technologically to colonize our solar system? Yes, I think we can do so even sooner than 400 years, probably within a 100 provided:The reason it is so hard to predict what the state of human space colonization would be around 400 years in the future is that the rate of technological advancement is exponential, and often as a civilization we underestimate what we can achieve. There was a time when Lord Kelvin said "Heavier than air flying machines are impossible", and today air travel is part and parcel of our lives.Do I think we can advance technologically to colonize our solar system? Yes, I think we can do so even sooner than 400 years, probably within a 100 provided:(2) Deal with the hazards and long-term survival implications for humans in such a situation. We would need a reasonable eco-system to make a colony self-sustaining, adequate radiation shielding in-case of a thinner atmosphere and ways to keep the muscular and skeletal system from degrading in a lower gravity environment. I don't know what the implications would be for children born on colonies, and if they would ever be able to return to Earth.Wormhole travel is some distance away, since at this point we don't even have observable evidence of wormholes, only mathematical solutions that indicate their existence. Even if we could find one, we would likely need a large amount of energy to create and sustain one large enough to travel through it.

Answer: Will humans advance technologically to be able to colonize almost every habitable planet in our solar system by year 2400?That's easy. We have already fully colonized every habitable planet in our solar system. The Earth is the only human habitable planet in our solar system, but I'm sure that's not what you really meant.I think it almost certain that we will eventually have the technology to visit (as in "land and plant a flag on") any of the solid outer planets or moons. It is much more costly and difficult to set up a habitable research outpost because the outpost would have to provide fulWill humans advance technologically to be able to colonize almost every habitable planet in our solar system by year 2400?That's easy. We have already fully colonized every habitable planet in our solar system. The Earth is the only human habitable planet in our solar system, but I'm sure that's not what you really meant.I think it almost certain that we will eventually have the technology to visit (as in "land and plant a flag on") any of the solid outer planets or moons. It is much more costly and difficult to set up a habitable research outpost because the outpost would have to provide fully enclosed, heated and shielded living environments. Those are necessarily going to be big and heavy and our only way to get them into space is probably going to be more elaborate versions of our current chemical rockets.The best analogy is the ISS, assembled in orbit over a decade. Apollo missions and the ISS demonstrated you can get a lot of mass into space if you have enough rockets and enough patience to do it.Sticking the landing is always the hard part. We are used to the idea of Earth re-entry where we let the air slow us down and then pop parachutes and land somewhat gently. That can't work on a planet that doesn't have a nice thick atmosphere like ours. Mars doesn't and most of the other interesting places have none at all. So getting something heavy on the ground in one piece is always going to be a challenge.We might come up with a smarter way, but for the foreseeable future  it would have to be the same as the moon landing, i.e. Using chemical rockets like smaller versions of the ones used to take off in the first place. That means much more fuel has to be carried and less payload can be carried.You define a colony as 100 people on Mars, 1,000 on Moon, 1 Each on other moons and planets. I disagree with your notion of "colony" in the sense that none of those places could ever be self sustaining (well, I guess never say never, but let's call it extraordinarily unlikely). So while you might succeed in landing that many people on those places, they would always require re-supply from Earth and hence could not be considered colonies. Just outposts in the same way the ISS is an outpost today.You ask "I wonder if there are any PE firms that make 300 year plans?" And again, that's easy. No there are none today and likely there won't be hundreds of years in the future. Private Equity focuses on a fairly short term (i.e. A few years) time horizon because their investors want to get paid. No private interest is going to make a multi-generational commitment with no profit at the end. There is nothing out there that would be worth overcoming the sheer physical difficulty of bringing it back.You ask "How likely is traveling through wormholes?". This is more speculative of course, since there is no evidence at all that wormholes exist. They are theoretical constructs, so there is some non-zero chance they might exist somewhere out there. It's a big universe after all. Personally, I don't believe they exist at all, so that would be a "no".
